sub_topic: Identifying the clique number of a graph.
message_1:
Consider a simple graph with 6 vertices labeled V1, V2, V3, V4, V5, and V6. The edges in the graph are as follows:

V1-V2, V1-V3, V1-V4, V2-V3, V2-V4, V3-V4, V4-V5, and V5-V6.

What is the clique number of this graph?
message_2:
The clique number of a graph is the size of the largest complete subgraph (clique) in the graph. A complete subgraph is a subgraph where every pair of vertices is connected by an edge.

In this graph, we can see that there is a complete subgraph formed by vertices V1, V2, V3, and V4, as all pairs of these vertices are connected by edges:

V1-V2, V1-V3, V1-V4, V2-V3, V2-V4, and V3-V4.

There is no larger complete subgraph in this graph. Therefore, the clique number of this graph is 4.
